comments.commentBody:
There is absolutely no hope the US will ever solve the more pressing problems of economic recovery, wage disparity, national debt, foreign intanglements and declining educational system if we get distracted by every lunatic who does something tasteless and crass. Mr. Jones has every Constitutional right to burn whatever he wants to burn on his own property (local fire codes notwithstanding). The US media has every right to pass this sorry waste of carbon by and report on issues having more direct effect on our daily lives. All symbolism and posturing aside, covering these desperate cries for attention is going to inspire every other low-life with a grudge to find creative ways to insult or endanger some other segment of the population. Americans used to shrug their shoulders when confronted with the weird, nasty and aberrant. Now it seems we are all professionally offended at the least consequential gesture. We've lost our position as world thought leaders, trend setters and inventors because we are focused on the most depraved and extreme ends of the bell curve.

Suggestion: I'd rather read about the proposed round #2 of the stimulus, the funding for stem cell research, and any new technology breakthroughs. That may actually have some effect on the lives of Americans.

So... this is what I (a life long devout Christian) promise my Muslim neighbors... for every Koran burned I will burn two Bibles. Don't let this evil man make us enemies. We are not. We love God, however we define him. I would lay down my life to protect you. This is my promise.

Exactly! How about I and my few friends organize a Koran burning next weekend? Would we get calls from all the important people and be featured on TeeVee? Because we can!

(But we won't)

Andrei Vorobiev
CorruptionManagement.com

I think the good reverend should go ahead with his original plan and exercise his right to free speech, regardless of whether anyone photographs it or reports on it nationally or internationally.

As he himself stated, the violence that results from this is not his doing, but reflects the inner urge to violence of those Islamic protestors who harbor animosity towards all Westerners in the first place.

Yes they want you to take away the freedom of religion of these people because if we do that then we are next and we destroy our constitution and country this way. We are no longer America, We are corporate American and they have sold us out to every country in the book. The majority of important real estate does not belong to Americans at all..

Dont we just love this negative religious propaganda while they deviate our attention from actually helping us with Jobs and creating an upward mobility for each American? This innocent negativity of trying to take others constitutional rights is the type of patriotism that destroys the foundation of this country.

Why not help this entire country elevate beyond a - borrowed to death and owed to death - spiral of Americanism that is plundering our Treasury and Country to the ground.

Lets get real here, We are becoming third rate and less superpower by the minute..
I wish the navel-gazing had come before the press turned a small-time histrionic into a national security problem.

The thing I dread is the copy cats. Now that people know how easily the press is manipulated, Pandora's box is wide open.

Let's see what other obscure lunatics who think they deserve their 15 minutes of fame end up pulling out of their hats.

You know in a nation of 300 million, there are a lot of lunatics.

Absolutely.  This ridiculous tiny revolt was certainly not worth mentioning beyond it's local fanatics.  Due to the media's continued poor choices this was given international credibility against our country.

There is no question that much of today's media coverage is irresponsible. The quality of electronic news reporting was in decline before 1996 FCC deregulation and the formation of the internet. FCC deregulation exponentially expanded irresponbile electronic journalism. The internet is obviously little more than an international back fence that has the potential to ignite false
alarms and major "fires". We should be thankful that a few quality
newspapers remain, but for how long? Has responsibility become an
anachronism in this country?

Burning of bibles in public is a NO No in the US, there are many different types of bibles that need to be protected. If the Koran is allowed to be burned, the Mormon bible could be next. Its not only about not angering those in Afghanistan but protecting freedom of religion in America.

Mainstream media could have ignored this.Like the controversioal Danish cartoon  intially did attract lot of negative backlash but another one will not be able to attract the same  level negativism.Hopefully if another nutty character threatens to repeat the FL pastor's threat it may be able to generate much backlash.

The media continues to pander at any cost.  The Terry Jones' story would have gone nowhere without our infotainment industry.  Additionally, terrorists would have no voice and no power without the media.

As has been mentioned numerous times the media circus may be at fault here. On one level we do have relatively intelligent journalism taking place. On the other hand we have a need for stories that drive ratings. While the thoughtful intelligent journalism can be found, what is normally hawked and consumed by the larger share of the public is the sensationalist, “yellow journalism,” that does indeed drive rating by appeal to fear, the easy solutions, and a general formula that dictates a recipe of “bread and circuses,” for the masses. If this is a problem at the national level of broadcast, it is even more so at the local level with affiliates being little more then prostitutes for advertisers. Ask your self how much truly relevant news you find on your local stations. It's about revenue and sales, and Terry Jones was just one more shill for a low brow, low expectation media mind set.

I am a somewhat devout Muslim, but I have to say that the media frenzy over this Quran burning event was above and beyond any reason or rationale. Media turned it into a circus and gave the pastor the importance that he never merited. I am of the opinion that this event had less to do with Muslim sensitivities and more to do with media trying to stir up some ratings. Personally, I would not have been offended if pastor had burned the Qurans. Burning any book, whether it is a cheap novel, a holy book, or a classic literature, reflects poorly on the person setting fire than on the people who love those books.
Favre was terrible.

comments.userDisplayName: Variations on a Theme of Paul
comments.commentBody: Pretty ugly game all around. Favre is definitely out of sync with his receivers. That will get better in the coming weeks. Glad to see they at least protected him. Good to be watching games that count again.

arthur118 is often my Mr. OY VEY Pencil.  Tonight he corrected me at 41A where I had BIG PAPPA (thinking Papi, I suppose?) instead of POPPA.  Dumb mistake, but I was so impressed with myself at that point (a Friday in under 30 minutes!) that I rushed to the blog without looking things over.  My favorite word in the puzzle: DULCIMER.  Never knew it had that meaning...  Sweet.

There is a double standard. America is for equality. One man rights should be protected. The troops are protecting oil investments not the American people. Freedom of SPEECH and Values. I Love America, LOVE it or LEAVE it .
The US media elevated this crazy person to a national figure.  He does not represent me or my friends.

Burning of the Koran is an inflammatory act that would lead to the death of American troops and serve as a recruitment tool for al qaeda.
How is this different from the NY Times publishing of the Abu Ghraib photos and subsequent 43 front page stories regarding the incident?

"This week’s events were the culmination of a year’s worth of hateful statements and stunts by Mr. Jones and the few dozen members of his church."

No, this week's events were the culmination of more than two years' worth of hateful racism spewed by the entire right wing. In 2004, they demonized gay people; now they're demonizing Mexicans and Muslims.

And the media has happily given these dopes a megaphone because it's loud and colorful and wacky. They don't hold anyone accountable for stating facts correctly or demonstrating a basic understanding of the U.S. Constitution. They allow people to rewrite recent history without comment. They don't care that they've amplified ugly misplaced anger that's one step away from serious violence. No, the press has been a happy, willing pawn in the whole nasty game.

Actually covering the details of the myriad serious policy problems we face is simply too much work, especially for the fine folks on the teevee. Every ignorant tweet from Sarah Palin is covered breathlessly, and every wacky birther is taken seriously, but these "reporters" can't be bothered to follow up on billions in Iraqi reconstruction money that disappeared or what kind of godawful conflicts of interest lay behind the bank bailouts.

I am really afraid for our democracy.

Once upon a time, the media didn't dignify the racism and factually incorrect rants of every crazy loon on the fringe--and our national discourse was a whole lot saner for it. Here's a tip: If somebody is a nut, don't hand them a microphone.
"each time expressing his extremist views about Islam and Sharia law."... hey, he's a wingnut but the only 'extremist' view one can hold about Sharia Law (thanks for the caps) is to be opposed to it.

It's true, the media has wasted everyone's time with the Pastor Jones saga. However, what made the story compelling was the very real threat of violence that surrounded the burning of the Koran.

Had Terry Jones planned to burn the holy book of some non-excitable religious group, like Mormons or Amish, the media would have yawned.

The idea that there is a "summer news lull" is just insane. I spent June in Haiti- things there are not OK. The crisis there is ongoing and happening right now. It should be headlines every day. Pakistan is in the middle of an absolutely massive catastrophe. The flood waters are the perfect conditions for growing extremism, and the US population has not been as engaged as they would be if it were in the news more. Systematic rapes are occurring in Congo and it barely makes headlines.

This cult leader from Florida would deserve no attention even *if* a "summer news lull" existed. Giving him so much attention while so many human beings need help is just more evidence that the US media cares only about spectacle.

This happens all too often...the news media messes up and then reports on itself.

This story had no redeeming value and was nothing more than sensationalism and a fanning the a fires of fear and suspicion among the Muslim communities everywhere.

Oh yeah...it got people to tune-in or drop a few quarters at the news stand. Shame on the press...
